entries.title: The Apothecary Diaries 2nd Season
entries.jpTitle: 薬屋のひとりごと 第2期（第2クール）

review.en: From ghost stories and bug obsession to color blindness—every odd piece from earlier episodes, and everything else we've seen so far, was part of this devastating build-up. The storyline involving western bloodlines, nobles, and royalty ran so deep, it was overwhelming. I'm sorry—I'm at a loss for words. But what I can say is, it was so profound, so powerful, so heartbreaking... it brought me to tears. Absolutely stunning...

entries.title: The Catcher in the Ballpark!
entries.jpTitle: ボールパークでつかまえて！

review.en: Simply a perfect episode. Every part was tightly woven together—even with episodes from the past—and the emotional payoff was overwhelming. While keeping its light-hearted charm, all three segments truly hit home. The Kojiro and Tsubaki story? Cheat-level excellence. (Tsubaki and Sanshiro, by the way, are classically linked names in Japanese pop culture—think Tsubaki Sanjuro.) Who could watch that arc without tearing up? And the ending? That special ED song and animation crafted specifically for this episode—too much. It paired so perfectly with everything we’d just seen. Sorry, I can’t even see the screen anymore...

I didn’t expect the transition from Edo to Heisei to hit this hard—it was subtle, but so cleverly done it caught me off guard. The play, written by Yotaka (yep, the prostitute from the Edo arc), nailed the essence of the story and its characters. And the fact that the Heisei students were watching it, commenting on it—cracking up over how uncool Jinya’s role was—just made it all land even harder.
There was this quiet sense of nostalgia layered under the humor, like you’re laughing but also feeling the weight of everything that’s been lost. And the way they used traditional theater pacing and structure? Absolutely nailed it. It was tight, emotional, and totally immersive. No question—solid 10

Wow… Elmes. A vessel of timeless, transcendental beauty — serene, sacred, and strangely universal… no — multi-universal — which stretches across dimensions.This isn’t something that can or should be evaluated by the same standards as other shows this season.It was a brilliant and enigmatic encounter — a true Meguriai Sora moment.

Details, details... what a beautifully crafted episode. The juxtaposition of past and present, and all the leading and misleading elements are meticulously assembled like a piece of art. That nurse — is she the reason Osanai never shows up when Kobato’s awake? Is she deliberately avoiding her? The way the story reveals the uniform — through Kobato, Osanai, and the junior witness — is a quintessential portrayal of intricate storytelling—painstakingly detailed, quiet, yet viscerally powerful, and overwhelming awe.. Anyway, there’s no way I could give this an 8. Thumbs up.

entries.title: From Old Country Bumpkin to Master Swordsmane
entries.jpTitle: 片田舎のおっさん、剣聖になる

review.en: Old bumpkin oddly looked so young (in the battle scenes)— just like someone else in his early 20s (and even good looking!). Otherwise, it was a good episode with solid battle scenes, and of course, our idol Myui delivered.

entries.title: Kowloon Generic Romance
entries.jpTitle: 九龍ジェネリックロマンス

review.en: Finally back to the beauty of ordinary life in extraordinary Kowloon. Without it, the show loses interest — regardless of how intriguing the mystery is. And honestly, the story should really be moving forward by now — not just circling around the edges. It still feels like it's stalling.

entries.title: Can a Boy-Girl Friendship Survive?
entries.jpTitle: 男女の友情は成立する？（いや、しないっ!!）
